> John Arrowwood wrote:
>  I'm asking it not to identify features and classify them, I'm
> >asking it to form a mathematical model, and query that model.  But that's
> >not what an ANN does, does it? 

Why not?

Isn't there a theorem somewhere demonstrating that a multi-layer ANN
can approximate any continuous function?

I'm pretty interested in how your project is going, since we might be
considering using a neural network to perform some sort of
pre-processing on our images before identification by the eye.

Is anyone on the list familiar with binarization?  It's basically the
process of converting all the greyscale values of a greyscale image to
either black or white, in order to simplify, clarify, or sharpen an
image for further processing.  It's used, for example, to distinguish
foreground from background.

This probably won't be much use for our current data set, but if we're
processing more complicated images, especially those with low contrast
or a lot of background noise, we may want to apply some sort of
binarization technique before showing it to the ANN eye for
identification.

The simplest and crudest binarization function simply reads the value
of each pixel, and if it's below a particular threshold value (e.g.
177 out of 256 greyscale values), it sets the value to 0, and if it's
above the threshold it sets it to 1.  More complicated functions take
into consideration the contrast in a particular area and dynamically
adjust the threshold accordingly.  For example, one technique uses a
formula which calculates the threshold based on the mean pixel value
and standard deviation for the 15x15 region around a given pixel.

Such a function could be performed by a neural network, right?  And
such an approach is similar to what you're trying to achieve, isn't
it?

Derek
